- This proposition involves the disjunction of p3 (\sqrt{3} is irrational) and p4 (5 is irrational).

- This proposition requires a more complex logical combination. It means that one among p3 and p4 must be true, while the other must be false.

To determine whether the given formulas are Truth Formulas, Falsehood Formulas, or Neither, we'll analyze each formula according to the logic rules provided.

#### (1) ~(p1=::>p2)&p2

- p1=::>p2 means "if p1, then p2"

Step 2: Negate the implication.
- ~(p1=::>p2) will be true in the same situations where p1=::>p2 is false, i.e., when p1 is true and p2 is false (✓|x).

Step 3: Combine with p2 using "and".
- ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 will be true only if both ~(p1=::>p2) is true and p2 is true.
- For ~(p1=::>p2) to be true, p1 must be true and p2 must be false. However, for p2 itself to be true, this creates a contradiction because p2 cannot be both false and true at the same time. Hence, this formula cannot be true under any assignment. It is a Falsehood Formula.

#### (2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)

Step 1: Understand both sides of the equivalence.
- On the left side, (p1&p3) is true if both p1 and p3 are true.
- On the right side, (~p1&~p2) is true if both ~p1 and ~p2 are true, which means p1 and p2 must both be false.

Step 2: Combine both sides using equivalence.
- (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)
- For the equivalence to be true, both sides must have the same truth value. However, (p1&p3) is true only if p1 and p3 are true, while (~p1&~p2) is true only if p1 and p2 are false. It is impossible for both conditions to be true simultaneously because p1 cannot be both true (for the left side) and false (for the right side). Thus, this formula is a Falsehood Formula.
